captions.text:
"HEY LOOK! There's Indonesia!
Oh yeah!"

(laughs) 
"You're such a dork"
"I'm tired.."

It took us just over 5 days to
make the 700 mile sail

from Darwin, Australia to The
Spice Islands, Indonesia.
It was a great sail.

We had awesome weather and wind
for most of the trip and just
started to get into the groove
when suddenly we arrived.

I called up some boats on the
VHF to see what the mooring
situation was at the village
quay.

It's always a bit intense
entering a new country for the
first time

and we weren't sure what to
expect.
"Just arrived in Banda!"
"Spice Islands, Indonesia"
"And we didn't prepare enough..
so Karin is sewing..

An Indonesian Flag for us right
now"

After the long trip the girls
were feeling like some Yoga.

It was a short commute since
we were stern tied
just a few meters from shore.

Brady decided to join the girls
and made a valiant effort at a
headstand of sorts.

I decided to watch from the
comfort of Delos,

where I could be entertained
AND enjoy my Ice Cold Bintang
at the same time.

I couldn't wait to get in the
water.
It was so good to swim again!

We hadn't been snorkeling in
ages, mostly due to those pesky
saltwater crocs back in
Australia.

Our first snorkel in Indonesia
didn't disappoint.
The water was clear

And the coral was healthy and
alive

So cool to see in an area that
was destroyed by a volcanic
lava flow not too long ago.

It's impressive how quickly
nature can recover if left to
do her own thing.

Our new dinghy Maggie takes
some practice to get into.

Karin and Josje are old hands
but Nina needs just a little
more practice.

I suppose we could have given
her a hand but well..
She's gotta learn right?

The next day we decided to hop
on a local boat for a tour

of a nutmeg plantation, the
literal heart of the spice
islands.

With a fish hook holding the
throttle for cruise control

and me on lookout duty we were
in full tourist mode.

We'd heard so much about these
far off Islands in Eastern
Indonesia,

these small specs in the middle
of the Banda Sea that most
people have heard of, but very
few venture to.

We were excited to start
exploring and Nina wasted no
time getting acquainted with
the local goat population.

Brady and I watched two kids
play that all time favorite

'beat my brother with a palm
frond'

It was so good to be in a
different culture again.

We loved Australia but there's
nothing like traveling to far
off islands, well off the
beaten track.
Before leaving the village

we visited the town well to
bless ourselves, a tradition
that's help up for generations.

The locals swear the water has
magical and healing qualities.

We emerged from the village to
find a scooter gang willing to
give us a ride.

With small dirt roads scooters
are the transport of choice in
these islands.

Westerners aren't a common site
here..

so we got our share of waves
and stares.

We arrived at the plantation to
find massive almond trees
stretching hundreds of feet
into the air.

Most of these trees are 400
years old.

They weren't planted for their
tasty nuts,

but to shade the really
valuable merchandise......
The nutmeg!

Nutmeg has been picked here for
centuries and not much has
changed.

Nutmeg is really tempermantal
and won't just grow anywhere.

Banda just happens to have the
right mix of climate and soil
for the spice to thrive.

At one point the Spice Islands
provided nearly all the nutmeg,
cloves,

mace, and cinnamon for most of
Europe.

In the Spice Race Portugal, the
English, and the Dutch battled
it out for control of the these
gems.

European powers of the age sent
huge armadas of ships and built
massive fortresses.

The Dutch won and built an
empire on the spoils. With a
monopoly on the spices,

,the Dutch built the cities of
Amsterdam and Rotterdam.

They increased the prices until
at one point nutmeg was
actually worth MORE than it's
weight in gold.

It was at a huge human cost
though. The local Bandanese
were enslaved,

their chieftains slaughtered or
held captive while the general
population was forced to work
the Nutmeg plantations.

Most of the local population
perished,

while providing the means to
build cities they would never
see.

Imagine all that power, wealth,
and greed

released just because the
contents of these little shells
were so delicious when dried
over an open fire.

But now the Bandanese are doing
well for themselves. The
Europeans have gone home,

and the local system of sultans
once again rules.

The past is remembered, but not
dwelled upon. There aren't any
grudges held.

It's a part of their history
and everyone is looking toward
the future.

The grand houses where the
oppressors

once ruled from are now owned
by local entruenuers.

Slowly they're being restored,
and turned into cozy bed and
breakfasts
..with an Indonesian flair!

Abba and his wife brought us
into their home and cooked us
wonderful, traditional
Indonesian meals.

We even got a cooking lesson
with some local recipes.

Tourism is on the rise but it's
still a pretty sleepy place.

Roosters and baby goats wander
the streets in harmony.

The fast food joint is this
street cart that just happens
to serve our favorite
Indonesian dish!
Mie Go Rang!

We got on so well with Abba we
asked him to sail to Ambon with
us as our personal guide!

So, if you ever make it to
Banda Neira be sure to check
his place out. It's real sweet.
Up next!
The crew climbs a volcano
and sets sail for Ambon.

comments.author: MrBiodiversity

comments.text:
Not that it means shit, but what kind of camera? And how you use mics? 
Myself, I use a Canon XA10. - - My dream is a catamaran, a Lagoon 500 or a 
Lagoon 620 (if I get really rich on my writings :-) )﻿
comments.author: Sverre Årnes

comments.text: +Brian SV Delos Well, what makes the job done, makes the job done :-)
comments.author: Sverre Årnes

comments.text:
Hey Sverre!Our primary camera is a pretty cheap Canon HFM500.  We also use 
a GoPro 
for some Wide Angle shots.  Underwater footage uses a Canon G15 in a 
FantaSea dive case.  We're pretty amatuer and really can't afford much gear 
so just use the built in camera mic.  We use Adobe Premiere and our laptops 
on board for 
the editing.  I'm happy to say everything is charged\powered 100% with 
solar power as well.  Life on a boat is good!Good luck with that massive 
Lagoon!  Would be a hell of a cruising boat :)Cheers to you and thanks 
again for watching!BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Gosh, I'm impressed, and I am stiff of envy! You write good text, and the 
narrator is real good - a charming, enthusiastic voice. Do you have an 
editing suite onboard? I just wonder. Myself, used Adobe Premiere for 
almost 20 years :-)﻿
comments.author: Sverre Årnes

comments.text:
Hey Sverre- Oh now we're really blushing :)  It's funny because we do all 
this on board so if you listen closely you can sometimes hear waves hitting 
the boat or outboards going by or the wind in the rigging.  It's authentic 
though!  We use Adobe Premiere and it works great.Thanks so much for 
watching!Fair Winds,BrianS\V Delos

comments.text:
10 years ago i worked 12 hours every day 7 days a week to save enough money 
to go on a trip very much similar to yours. 3 friends and i was supposed to 
start out late April 2004 from Denmark, 20 March i fractured my back on the 
job..

So you guys, enjoy every second of your dreamtrip, and thank you so much 
for sharing your videos with the world, it is very much appriciated. You 
guys surely make me envy you, but it is a goodenvy as thru you i feel i 
explore to.

The videos and the drawings are amazing :D﻿

comments.author: joker rc

comments.text:
The crew gets situated in Band Neira, Indonesia after our sail from 
Australia. We do a bit of yoga, hit the water for some snorkeling, then get 
to the heart of the Spice Islands by touring a nutmeg plantation and Dutch 
fortress.﻿
comments.author: SV Delos Crew
